intro: Dissochaeta annulata var. johannis-winkleri, commonly known as the Winkler's hairless dissochaeta, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the family Rubiaceae and is characterized by its slender, hairy stems and small, white or pinkish flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to arid or semi-arid environments. Its leaves are usually opposite and have a slightly hairy texture, while its fruits are small, dry capsules that release seeds when mature. This variant is noted for its distinctive morphology and is of interest to botanists studying regional plant diversity.
